Sharper Convergence Guarantees for Asynchronous SGD for Distributed and Federated Learning

Anastasia Koloskova
EPFL
anastasia.koloskova@epfl.ch
&Sebastian U. Stich
CISPA
stich@cispa.de
&Martin Jaggi
EPFL
martin.jaggi@epfl.ch
Abstract

We study the asynchronous stochastic gradient descent algorithm for distributed training over nğ‘›n workers which have varying computation and communication frequency over time. In this algorithm, workers compute stochastic gradients in parallel at their own pace and return those to the server without any synchronization. Existing convergence rates of this algorithm for non-convex smooth objectives depend on the maximum gradient delay Ï„maxsubscriptğœ\tau_{\max} and show that an Îµğœ€\varepsilon-stationary point is reached after ğ’ªâ€‹(Ïƒ2â€‹Îµâˆ’2+Ï„maxâ€‹Îµâˆ’1)ğ’ªsuperscriptğœ2superscriptğœ€2subscriptğœsuperscriptğœ€1\mathcal{O}\!\left(\sigma^{2}\varepsilon^{-2}+\tau_{\max}\varepsilon^{-1}\right) iterations, where Ïƒğœ\sigma denotes the variance of stochastic gradients.
In this work (i) we obtain a tighter convergence rate of ğ’ªâ€‹(Ïƒ2â€‹Îµâˆ’2+Ï„maxâ€‹Ï„aâ€‹vâ€‹gâ€‹Îµâˆ’1)ğ’ªsuperscriptğœ2superscriptğœ€2subscriptğœsubscriptğœğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘”superscriptğœ€1\mathcal{O}\!\left(\sigma^{2}\varepsilon^{-2}+\sqrt{\tau_{\max}\tau_{avg}}\varepsilon^{-1}\right) without any change in the algorithm whereÂ Ï„aâ€‹vâ€‹gsubscriptğœğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘”\tau_{avg} is the average delay, which can be significantly smaller than Ï„maxsubscriptğœ\tau_{\max}. We also provide (ii) a simple delay-adaptive learning rate scheme, under which asynchronous SGD achieves a convergence rate of ğ’ªâ€‹(Ïƒ2â€‹Îµâˆ’2+Ï„aâ€‹vâ€‹gâ€‹Îµâˆ’1)ğ’ªsuperscriptğœ2superscriptğœ€2subscriptğœğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘”superscriptğœ€1\mathcal{O}\!\left(\sigma^{2}\varepsilon^{-2}+\tau_{avg}\varepsilon^{-1}\right), and does not require any extra hyperparameter tuning nor extra communications. Our result allows to show for the first time that asynchronous SGD is always faster than mini-batch SGD. In addition, (iii) we consider the case of heterogeneous functions motivated by federated learning applications and improve the convergence rate by proving a weaker dependence on the maximum delay compared to prior works. In particular, we show that the heterogeneity term in convergence rate is only affected by the average delay within each worker.

1 Introduction

The stochastic gradient descent (SGD) algorithm [42, 12] and its variants (momentum SGD, Adam, etc.) form the foundation of modern machine learning and frequently achieve state of the art results. With recent growth in the size of models and available training data, parallel and distributed versions of SGD are becoming increasingly importantÂ [55, 16, 15]. Without those, modern state-of-the art language models [43], generative modelsÂ [39, 40], and many othersÂ [49] would not be possible. In the distributed setting, also known as data-parallel training, optimization is distributed over many compute devices working in parallel (e.g. cores, or GPUs on a cluster) in order to speed up training. Every worker computes gradients on a subset of the training data, and the resulting gradients are aggregated (averaged) on a server.

The same type of SGD variants also form the core algorithms for federated learning applicationsÂ [33, 23] where the training process is naturally distributed over the user devices, or clients, that keep their local data private, and only transfer the (e.g. encrypted or differentially private) gradients to the server.

A rich literature exists on the convergence theory of above mentioned parallel SGD methods, see e.g. [16, 12] and references therein. Plain parallel SGD still faces many challenges in practice, motivating research on various approaches to improve efficiency of distributed learning and mini-batch SGD. This includes for example communication compression techniques [2, 3, 47, 48], decentralized communication [28, 6, 35, 25] or performing several local SGD steps on workers before communicating with the server [29, 31, 33, 46].

These approaches use synchronous communication, where workers in each round are required to wait for the slowest one, before being able to start the next round of computations. In the presence of such straggler nodes or nodes that have different computation speeds, other workers face significant idle times. Asynchronous variants of SGD are aimed to solve such inefficiencies and use available workers more effectively. In asynchronous SGD, each worker starts the next computation immediately after finishing computing its own gradient, without waiting for any other workers. This is especially important in the presence of straggler nodes. Asynchronous algorithms were studied both in distributed and federated learning settings [41, 30, 26, 45, 36]. In this paper we focus on such challenging asynchronous variants of SGD and provide an improved theoretical analysis of convergence compared to prior works.

Most existing work has studied the convergence behavior of asynchronous SGD for the setting of homogeneous distributed training data, where workerâ€™s objectives are i.i.d. . This assumption however is only realistic e.g. in shared-memory implementations where all processes can access the same dataÂ [41]. Under this assumption, it can be proven that asynchronous SGD finds an Îµğœ€\varepsilon-approximate stationary point (squared gradient norm bounded by Îµğœ€\varepsilon) in ğ’ªâ€‹(Ïƒ2Îµ2+Ï„maxÎµ)ğ’ªsuperscriptğœ2superscriptğœ€2subscriptğœğœ€\mathcal{O}\big{(}\frac{\sigma^{2}}{\varepsilon^{2}}+\frac{\tau_{\max}}{\varepsilon}\big{)} iterationsÂ [47], for smooth non-convex functions. This complexity bound depends on the maximum delay of the gradients Ï„maxsubscriptğœ\tau_{\max} and the gradient variance Ïƒ>0ğœ0\sigma>0. Unfortunately, the maximal delay is a very pessimistic metric, not well reflecting the true behavior in practice. For instance, if a worker struggles just once, the maximum delay is large, while we would still expect reasonable overall convergence.

Two recent works [14, 8] tackle this issue by proposing two new delay-adaptive algorithms that achieve a convergence rate that depends only on the average delay of the applied gradients, with Aviv etÂ al. [8] considering only the convex optimization and Cohen etÂ al. [14] providing a rate of ğ’ªâ€‹(Ïƒ2Îµ2+Ï„aâ€‹vâ€‹gÎµ)ğ’ªsuperscriptğœ2superscriptğœ€2subscriptğœğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘”ğœ€\mathcal{O}\big{(}\frac{\sigma^{2}}{\varepsilon^{2}}+\frac{\tau_{avg}}{\varepsilon}\big{)} for smooth non-convex functions. The average delay can be much smaller than the maximal delay, and thus these methods are robust to rare stragglers. However, Cohen etÂ al. [14] requires twice more communications at every step, and an extra hyperparameter to tune. Aviv etÂ al. [8] analyze only convex functions and assume a bound on the variance of the delays, which can frequently degrade with the maximum delay Ï„maxsubscriptğœ\tau_{\max}. Moreover, those works require the assumption that gradients are uniformly bounded.

In the realistic case of heterogeneous objective functions, that is in particular relevant in federated learning applicationsÂ [23], all the existent convergence rates of asynchronous SGD depend on the maximum delay [36].

2 Related Work

Asynchronous SGD.

The research field of asynchronous optimization can be traced back at least toÂ 1989 [10]. Recent works are heavily focused on its SGD variants, such as Hogwild! SGD [38] which deals with coordinate-wise asynchronity. Nguyen etÂ al. [37] provided a tighter convergence analysis by removing the bounded gradient assumption. Our work does not focus on such a coordinate-wise asynchrony as it relies on sparsity assumption that is not realistic in modern machine learning applications. Mania etÂ al. [30] introduces the perturbed iterate framework which enabled theoretical advances with tighter convergence ratesÂ [47, 45]. Leblond etÂ al. [26] focus on asynchronous variance-reduced methods.

Many works [1, 13, 19, 5, 44, 27, 47, 17] focused on asynchronous SGD variants where workers communicate with the server without any synchronization, but these communications are considered to be atomic. All of these works provide convergence guarantees that depend on the maximum delayÂ Ï„maxsubscriptğœ\tau_{\max} with [5, 47] providing the first tight convergence rates under assumption that the delays are always constant for quadratic and general (convex, strongly convex and non-convex) functions correspondingly. Stich etÂ al. [45] showed a connection of large batches and delays, although still depending only on the maximum delay. Even etÂ al. [18] consider a continuized view of the time (rather than classical per-iteration time) for asynchronous algorithms on a decentralized network.

Delay-adaptive methods.

The works [54, 53, 44, 50, 32, 17] considered delay-adaptive schemes to mitigate adversarial effect of stragglers, however with convergence rates that still depend on the maximum delay Ï„maxsubscriptğœ\tau_{\max}. Only Cohen etÂ al. [14] in the non-convex, and Aviv etÂ al. [8] in the convex case were able to obtain convergence rates depending on the average delay Ï„aâ€‹vâ€‹gsubscriptğœğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘”\tau_{avg}. Concurrent to our work, Mishchenko etÂ al. [34] provide a delay-adaptive scheme similar to ours and derive convergence guarantees depending on the concurrency Ï„Csubscriptğœğ¶\tau_{C}. However, they did not consider asynchronous SGD with constant stepsizes, nor the bounded gradients case. Moreover, for heterogeneous functions their method with delay adaptive stepsizes does not converge and only reaches an approximate solution (up to heterogeniety), while in our work we prove convergence for a different method with carefully tuned constant stepsizes.

Asynchronous federated learning.

In typical federated learning (FL) applications [33], clients or workers frequently have very different computing powers/speed. This makes especially appealing for practitioners to use asynchronous algorithms for FL [46, 36, 7, 52, 22, 9, 21, 51] with many of these works focusing on correcting for unequal participation ratio of different clients [51, 21, 22, 9, 52] by implementing variance reduction techniques on the server. Nguyen etÂ al. [36] introduce the FedBuff algorithm that is very close to the algorithm that we consider in this work and show its practical superiority over classical synchronous FL algorithms.

4 Homogeneous Distributed Setting

We start with an important special case of problem (1) where the objective functions are identical for all workers, i.e.Â fiâ€‹(ğ±)â‰¡fjâ€‹(ğ±)subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ±subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—ğ±f_{i}(\mathbf{x})\equiv f_{j}(\mathbf{x}) for all i,jâˆˆ[n]ğ‘–ğ‘—delimited-[]ğ‘›i,j\in[n], such as in the case of homogeneously (i.i.d.) distributed training data. Consequently, this implies that AssumptionÂ 2 holds with Î¶i=0subscriptğœğ‘–0\zeta_{i}=0, iâˆˆ[n]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›i\in[n]. Many classical works have focused on asynchronous algorithms under this homogeneous setting (e.g.Â [5, 47, 1, 19, 44, 27], see the related work for more references). This setting commonly appears in the datacenter setup for distributed training [15], where all nodes (or GPUs) have access to the full dataset or data distribution. Moreover, this special case allows us to present our main ideas in a simplified way, without complicating the presentation due to heterogeneity. We will later see that most of the results in this section can also be obtained as a corollary of the more general heterogeneous functions case (SectionÂ 5) by setting Î¶i=0â€‹iâˆˆ[n]subscriptğœğ‘–0ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›\zeta_{i}=0~{}i\in[n].

4.1 Algorithm

We consider standard asynchronous SGD (also known as delayed SGD, or SGD with stale updates) as presented in AlgorithmÂ 1, see e.g. [5, 47, 1, 19, 44, 27].

First, the server initializes training by selecting an initial active worker set ğ’0subscriptğ’0\mathcal{C}_{0} and assigning ğ±(0)superscriptğ±0\mathbf{x}^{(0)} to these workers. Throughout the algorithm, the active workers compute gradients at their own speed, based on their local data. On line 4, once some worker (which we denote as jtsubscriptğ‘—ğ‘¡j_{t}) finishes computing its gradient, it sends the result to the server. On line 5 the server incorporates the receivedâ€”possibly delayedâ€”gradient, using a stepsize Î·tsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡\eta_{t} that can depend on the gradient delay Ï„tsubscriptğœğ‘¡\tau_{t}. The gradient delay Ï„tsubscriptğœğ‘¡\tau_{t} is defined as the difference between the iteration at which worker jtsubscriptğ‘—ğ‘¡j_{t} started to compute the gradient and the iteration tğ‘¡t at which it got applied. We index the stochastic noise of the gradients Î¾tsubscriptğœ‰ğ‘¡\xi_{t} by iteration tğ‘¡t to highlight that previous iterates ğ±(tâ€²)superscriptğ±superscriptğ‘¡â€²\mathbf{x}^{(t^{\prime})} for tâ€²â‰¤tsuperscriptğ‘¡â€²ğ‘¡t^{\prime}\leq t do not depend on this stochastic noise. However, the client selects the data sample Î¾tsubscriptğœ‰ğ‘¡\xi_{t} at iteration tâˆ’Ï„tğ‘¡subscriptğœğ‘¡t-\tau_{t} when the computation starts. After that, on lines 6-7 the server selects the new active workers out of the ones that are currently inactive (including worker jtsubscriptğ‘—ğ‘¡j_{t}) and assigns them the latest iterateÂ ğ±(t+1)superscriptğ±ğ‘¡1\mathbf{x}^{(t+1)}.

In contrast to previous works, we explicitly define the set of workers that are busy with computations at every step tğ‘¡t as ğ’tsubscriptğ’ğ‘¡\mathcal{C}_{t} (the active workers set). Note that this does not pose any restrictions. A main advantage of allowing the sets ğ’tsubscriptğ’ğ‘¡\mathcal{C}_{t} to be different at every step tğ‘¡t lies in the possibility to also cover mini-batch SGD as a special case, which we discuss in ExampleÂ 2. Our theoretical results depend on the size of these sets ğ’tsubscriptğ’ğ‘¡\mathcal{C}_{t}, a.k.a. the concurrency.

Definition 1 (Concurrency).

The concurrency Ï„C(t)superscriptsubscriptğœğ¶ğ‘¡\tau_{C}^{(t)} at step tğ‘¡t is defined as the size of the active worker set ğ’tsubscriptğ’ğ‘¡\mathcal{C}_{t}, i.e. Ï„C(t)=|ğ’t|superscriptsubscriptğœğ¶ğ‘¡subscriptğ’ğ‘¡\tau_{C}^{(t)}=|\mathcal{C}_{t}|. We also define the maximum and average concurrency as

Ï„C=maxtâ¡{Ï„C(t)},subscriptğœğ¶subscriptğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğœğ¶ğ‘¡\displaystyle\tau_{C}=\max_{t}\{\tau_{C}^{(t)}\}\,, Ï„Â¯C=1T+1â€‹âˆ‘t=0TÏ„C(t).subscriptÂ¯ğœğ¶1ğ‘‡1superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡0ğ‘‡superscriptsubscriptğœğ¶ğ‘¡\displaystyle\bar{\tau}_{C}=\textstyle\frac{1}{T+1}\sum_{t=0}^{T}\tau_{C}^{(t)}\,.

Note that in many practical scenarios, we have a constant concurrency of nğ‘›n over time, meaning that all nğ‘›n workers are active at every step, and thus Ï„C=Ï„Â¯C=nsubscriptğœğ¶subscriptÂ¯ğœğ¶ğ‘›\tau_{C}=\bar{\tau}_{C}=n.

We discuss two important practical examples that fit into our AlgorithmÂ 1:

Example 2 (Mini-batch SGD).

Mini-batch SGD with batch size nğ‘›n can be seen as a special case of AlgorithmÂ 1, as follows: The server (i) in line 1 selects all nğ‘›n workers, ğ’0=[n]subscriptğ’0delimited-[]ğ‘›\mathcal{C}_{0}=[n]; (ii) in line 6 does not select new workers while the gradients from the same batch have not been fully applied yet, i.e. ğ’œt=âˆ…subscriptğ’œğ‘¡\mathcal{A}_{t}=\emptyset if tmodnâ‰ 0moduloğ‘¡ğ‘›0t\!\!\mod n\neq 0; (iii) in line 6 selects ğ’œt=[n]subscriptğ’œğ‘¡delimited-[]ğ‘›\mathcal{A}_{t}=[n] if tmodn=0moduloğ‘¡ğ‘›0t\!\!\mod n=0 to start a new batch.

Example 3 (Asynchronous SGD with maximum concurrency).

In practical implementations one should always aim to utilize all resources available and thus (i) in line 1 select all available workers ğ’0=0subscriptğ’00\mathcal{C}_{0}=0; (ii) in line 6 select the worker that finished its computations ğ’œt={jt}subscriptğ’œğ‘¡subscriptğ‘—ğ‘¡\mathcal{A}_{t}=\{j_{t}\} so that workers are always busy with jobs.

4.2 Theoretical analysis: Constant stepsizes

We first formally define the average and maximum delays.

Definition 4 (Average and maximum delays).

Let {Ï„t}t=0Tâˆ’1superscriptsubscriptsubscriptğœğ‘¡ğ‘¡0ğ‘‡1\{\tau_{t}\}_{t=0}^{T-1} be the delays of the applied gradients in AlgorithmÂ 1. We define {Ï„iğ’T}iâˆˆğ’T\{jT}subscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğœğ‘–subscriptğ’ğ‘‡ğ‘–\subscriptğ’ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘—ğ‘‡\{\tau_{i}^{\mathcal{C}_{T}}\}_{i\in\mathcal{C}_{T}\backslash\{j_{T}\}} as the delays of gradients which are in flight at time Tğ‘‡T, that is they have remained unapplied at the last step. Each Ï„iğ’Tsuperscriptsubscriptğœğ‘–subscriptğ’ğ‘‡\tau_{i}^{\mathcal{C}_{T}} is equal to the difference between the last iteration Tğ‘‡T and the iteration at which worker iğ‘–i started to compute its last gradient. We then define the average and the maximum delays as Ï„aâ€‹vâ€‹g=1T+|ğ’T|âˆ’1â€‹(âˆ‘t=0Tâˆ’1Ï„t+âˆ‘iâˆˆğ’T\{jT}Ï„iğ’T),subscriptğœğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘”1ğ‘‡subscriptğ’ğ‘‡1superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡0ğ‘‡1subscriptğœğ‘¡subscriptğ‘–\subscriptğ’ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘—ğ‘‡superscriptsubscriptğœğ‘–subscriptğ’ğ‘‡\displaystyle\tau_{avg}=\frac{1}{T+|\mathcal{C}_{T}|-1}\bigg{(}\sum_{t=0}^{T-1}\tau_{t}+\sum_{i\in\mathcal{C}_{T}\backslash\{j_{T}\}}\tau_{i}^{\mathcal{C}_{T}}\bigg{)}, Ï„max=maxâ¡{maxt=1,â€¦â€‹Tâˆ’1â¡Ï„t,maxiâˆˆğ’T\{jT}â¡Ï„iğ’T}.subscriptğœsubscriptğ‘¡1â€¦ğ‘‡1subscriptğœğ‘¡subscriptğ‘–\subscriptğ’ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘—ğ‘‡superscriptsubscriptğœğ‘–subscriptğ’ğ‘‡\displaystyle\tau_{\max}=\max\left\{\max_{t=1,\dots T-1}\tau_{t},\max_{i\in\mathcal{C}_{T}\backslash\{j_{T}\}}\tau_{i}^{\mathcal{C}_{T}}\right\}. (6)

We further provide a key observation on the connection between the average delay and the average concurrency. This observation, is one of the essential elements for achieving an improved analysis.

Remark 5 (Key Observation).

In AlgorithmÂ 1 the average concurrency Ï„Â¯CsubscriptÂ¯ğœğ¶\bar{\tau}_{C} is connected to the average delay Ï„aâ€‹vâ€‹gsubscriptğœğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘”\tau_{avg} as

Ï„aâ€‹vâ€‹g=T+1T+|CT|âˆ’1â€‹Ï„Â¯C=T>|CT|ğ’ªâ€‹(Ï„Â¯C).subscriptğœğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘”ğ‘‡1ğ‘‡subscriptğ¶ğ‘‡1subscriptÂ¯ğœğ¶superscriptğ‘‡subscriptğ¶ğ‘‡ğ’ªsubscriptÂ¯ğœğ¶\displaystyle\tau_{avg}=\frac{T+1}{T+|C_{T}|-1}\bar{\tau}_{C}~{}~{}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle T>|C_{T}|}}{{=}}~{}~{}\mathcal{O}\!\left(\bar{\tau}_{C}\right)\,. (7)

We explain this observation on a simple example. Assume that the concurrency is constant at every step (Ï„C=Ï„Â¯Csubscriptğœğ¶subscriptÂ¯ğœğ¶\tau_{C}=\bar{\tau}_{C}), and that all workers except one are responding very rarely. Then on steps 4â€“5 of AlgorithmÂ 1 only this one responding worker would mostly participate. This means that for this one worker the delay Ï„tsubscriptğœğ‘¡\tau_{t} would be frequently equal to zero, and the overall average delay will be small.

Next, we provide our theoretical results. We first focus on the Asynchronous SGD AlgorithmÂ 1 under constant stepsizes, i.e. Î·tâ‰¡Î·subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡ğœ‚\eta_{t}\equiv\eta. This setting was studied in many works such as [1, 19, 5, 27, 47]

If in AlgorithmÂ 1 the concurrency is constant at every step (thus Ï„C=Ï„Â¯Csubscriptğœğ¶subscriptÂ¯ğœğ¶\tau_{C}=\bar{\tau}_{C}), then under the same conditions as in TheoremÂ 6 the convergence rate of AlgorithmÂ 1 is

With an additional assumption of bounded gradients, the dependence on the maximum delay can be completely removed.

4.3 Theoretical analysis: Delay-adaptive stepsizes

In many cases, the bounded gradient AssumptionÂ 4 is unrealistic [37], meaning that the gradient bound GğºG is often large and thus the rate (9) is loose. In this section we show that by weighting the stepsize down for the gradients that have a large delay, once can remove the dependence on the maximum delay Ï„maxsubscriptğœ\tau_{\max} without assuming bounded gradients (Assump.Â 4).

Theorem 8 (Delay-adaptive stepsizes).

There exist a parameter Î·â‰¤14â€‹Lğœ‚14ğ¿\eta\leq\frac{1}{4L} such that if we set the stepsizes in AlgorithmÂ 1 dependent on the delays as

Î·t={Î·Ï„tâ‰¤Ï„C,<minâ¡{Î·,14â€‹Lâ€‹Ï„t}Ï„t>Ï„C,subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡casesğœ‚subscriptğœğ‘¡subscriptğœğ¶absentğœ‚14ğ¿subscriptğœğ‘¡subscriptğœğ‘¡subscriptğœğ¶\displaystyle\eta_{t}=\begin{cases}\eta&\tau_{t}\leq\tau_{C},\\ <\min\{\eta,\frac{1}{4L\tau_{t}}\}\vspace{-1mm}&\tau_{t}>\tau_{C},\end{cases} (11)

then for AlgorithmÂ 1, under AssumptionsÂ 1, 3 it holds that 1âˆ‘t=0TÎ·tâ€‹âˆ‘t=0TÎ·tâ€‹âˆ¥âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ±(t))âˆ¥22â‰¤Îµ1superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡0ğ‘‡subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡0ğ‘‡subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥âˆ‡ğ‘“superscriptğ±ğ‘¡22ğœ€\frac{1}{\sum_{t=0}^{T}\eta_{t}}\sum_{t=0}^{T}\eta_{t}\left\lVert\nabla f(\mathbf{x}^{(t)})\right\rVert_{2}^{2}\leq\varepsilon after

In our theorem, the stepsize Î·tsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡\eta_{t} in the case of large delays Ï„t>Ï„Csubscriptğœğ‘¡subscriptğœğ¶\tau_{t}>\tau_{C} can be an arbitrary value betweenÂ 00 and minâ¡{Î·,14â€‹Lâ€‹Ï„t}ğœ‚14ğ¿subscriptğœğ‘¡\min\{\eta,\frac{1}{4L\tau_{t}}\}. Setting the stepsize Î·tâ‰¡0subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡0\eta_{t}\equiv 0 is equivalent to dropping these gradients.

Proof sketch of TheoremÂ 8.

We give the intuitive proof sketch for the case when we drop gradients with Ï„t>Ï„Csubscriptğœğ‘¡subscriptğœğ¶\tau_{t}>\tau_{C} and we deal with the general case in the Appendix. We know that Ï„aâ€‹vâ€‹gâ‰ˆÏ„Â¯Câ‰¤Ï„Csubscriptğœğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘”subscriptÂ¯ğœğ¶subscriptğœğ¶\tau_{avg}\approx\bar{\tau}_{C}\leq\tau_{C} from RemarkÂ 5. It also holds that the number of gradients that have delay larger than the average delay Ï„aâ€‹vâ€‹gsubscriptğœğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘”\tau_{avg} is smaller than half of all the gradients (â‰¤T2absentğ‘‡2\leq\frac{T}{2}) because delays are bounded below by zero (Ï„tâ‰¥0â€‹âˆ€tsubscriptğœğ‘¡0for-allğ‘¡\tau_{t}\geq 0~{}\forall t). Thus, dropping the gradients with the delay Ï„t>Ï„Csubscriptğœğ‘¡subscriptğœğ¶\tau_{t}>\tau_{C}, or equivalently setting their stepsize Î·tâ‰¡0subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡0\eta_{t}\equiv 0, will degrade the convergence rate at most by half, while the maximum delay among the applied ones now is equal to Ï„Csubscriptğœğ¶\tau_{C}. Thus we can apply result from [47] with Ï„mâ€‹aâ€‹x=Ï„Csubscriptğœğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥subscriptğœğ¶\tau_{max}=\tau_{C}. âˆ

If in AlgorithmÂ 1 the concurrency is constant at every step (thus Ï„C=Ï„Â¯Csubscriptğœğ¶subscriptÂ¯ğœğ¶\tau_{C}=\bar{\tau}_{C}), then under the same conditions as in TheoremÂ 8 the convergence rate of AlgorithmÂ 1 is equal to

4.4 Discussion

Comparison to synchronous optimization.

Mini-batch SGD with batch size nğ‘›n has the same degree of parallelism as AlgorithmÂ 1 with constant concurrency nğ‘›n, i.e. it has nğ‘›n workers computing gradients in parallel. Mini-batch SGD needs ğ’ªâ€‹(Ïƒ2nâ€‹Îµ2+1Îµ)ğ’ªsuperscriptğœ2ğ‘›superscriptğœ€21ğœ€\mathcal{O}\big{(}\frac{\sigma^{2}}{n\varepsilon^{2}}+\frac{1}{\varepsilon}\big{)} [20] batches of gradients to reach an Îµğœ€\varepsilon-stationary point, and thus needs ğ’ªâ€‹(Ïƒ2Îµ2+nÎµ)ğ’ªsuperscriptğœ2superscriptğœ€2ğ‘›ğœ€\mathcal{O}\big{(}\frac{\sigma^{2}}{\varepsilon^{2}}+\frac{n}{\varepsilon}\big{)} gradients, as the batch-size is equal to nğ‘›n. On the contrary, asynchronous SGD AlgorithmÂ 1 with stepsizes chosen as in (11) achieves exactly the same rate (13) since Ï„aâ€‹vâ€‹g=Ï„C=nsubscriptğœğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘”subscriptğœğ¶ğ‘›\tau_{avg}=\tau_{C}=n, while its expected per-iteration time is faster than that of mini-batch SGD, as no workers have to wait for others. Thus, our result shows that asynchronous SGD is always faster than mini-batch SGD regardless of the delay pattern. A small note that in our reasoning we implicitly assumed that the sever can perform its operations in negligible time.

Tuning the stepsize.

It is worth noting that our stepsize rule (11) does not introduce any additional hyperparameters to tune compared to the constant stepsize case or to synchronous SGD. Ï„Csubscriptğœğ¶\tau_{C} is usually known and can be easily controlled by the server, especially in the practical constant concurrency case. Thus, to implement such a stepsize rule (11) one needs to tune only stepsize Î·ğœ‚\eta, and in case of Ï„t>Ï„Csubscriptğœğ‘¡subscriptğœğ¶\tau_{t}>\tau_{C} set stepsize Î·tâ‰¤Î·Ï„tsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡ğœ‚subscriptğœğ‘¡\eta_{t}\leq\frac{\eta}{\tau_{t}}.

Average v.s.Â maximum delay.

In a homogeneous environment when every worker computes gradients with same speed during the whole training, the average and maximum delays would be almost equal. However, occasional straggler devices will usually be present. In this case the maximum delay is much larger than the average delay.

Consider a simple example with n=2ğ‘›2n=2 workers, where the first worker computes gradients very fast, while the second worker returns its gradient only at the end of the training at the last iteration Tğ‘‡T. In this case the average delay Ï„aâ€‹vâ€‹g=2subscriptğœğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘”2\tau_{avg}=2 is a small constant, while the maximum delay Ï„max=Tsubscriptğœğ‘‡\tau_{\max}=T. In this case the rate depending only on the maximum delay Ï„maxsubscriptğœ\tau_{\max} would guarantee convergence only up to a constant accuracy Îµ=ğ’ªâ€‹(1)ğœ€ğ’ª1\varepsilon=\mathcal{O}(1). While both rates with Ï„maxâ€‹Ï„aâ€‹vâ€‹gsubscriptğœsubscriptğœğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘”\sqrt{\tau_{\max}\tau_{avg}} and with Ï„aâ€‹vâ€‹gsubscriptğœğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘”\tau_{avg} guarantee convergence up to an arbitrary small accuracy.

Comparison to other methods.

Cohen etÂ al. [14] recently proposed the PickySGD algorithm that achieves a convergence rate of ğ’ªâ€‹(Ïƒ2Îµ2+Ï„aâ€‹vâ€‹gÎµ)ğ’ªsuperscriptğœ2superscriptğœ€2subscriptğœğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘”ğœ€\mathcal{O}\big{(}\frac{\sigma^{2}}{\varepsilon^{2}}+\frac{{\tau_{avg}}}{\varepsilon}\big{)} (same as (13)). Their algorithm discards gradients based on the distance between the current point and the delayed one âˆ¥ğ±(t)âˆ’ğ±(tâˆ’Ï„t)âˆ¥delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥superscriptğ±ğ‘¡superscriptğ±ğ‘¡subscriptğœğ‘¡\left\lVert\mathbf{x}^{(t)}-\mathbf{x}^{(t-\tau_{t})}\right\rVert. The disadvantage of their method is that it requires sending points ğ±(tâˆ’Ï„t)superscriptğ±ğ‘¡subscriptğœğ‘¡\mathbf{x}^{(t-\tau_{t})} along with the gradients thus incurring twice more communications at every step. Their method also requires tuning an extra hyperparameter. In this work we achieve the same convergence rate with a much simpler method that does not require any additional communications nor additional tuning compared to synchronous SGD.

[8] also recently proposed the delay-adaptive algorithm with convergence rate depending on the average delay Ï„aâ€‹vâ€‹gsubscriptğœğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘”\tau_{avg} for the convex and strongly convex cases. Although, our convergence rates are for the non-convex case and are not directly comparable to theirs, we highlight some key differences in their analysis. First, their convergence rate depends not only on Ï„aâ€‹vâ€‹gsubscriptğœğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘”\tau_{avg} but also on the variance ÏƒÏ„subscriptğœğœ\sigma_{\tau} of the delays, which can degrade with the maximum delay. Second, they require the bounded gradient AssumptionÂ 4. In TheoremÂ 6 we show that under AssumptionÂ 4 no modifications to the algorithm are needed to completely remove the dependence on the maximum delay Ï„maxsubscriptğœ\tau_{\max} (9).

Tightness.

As we explained in ExampleÂ 2, mini-batch SGD is covered by AlgorithmÂ 1. We know that mini-batch SGD convergence is lower bounded by Î˜â€‹(Ïƒ2nâ€‹Îµ2+1Îµ)Î˜superscriptğœ2ğ‘›superscriptğœ€21ğœ€\Theta\big{(}\frac{\sigma^{2}}{n\varepsilon^{2}}+\frac{1}{\varepsilon}\big{)} [4] in terms of batches processed and thus by Î˜â€‹(Ïƒ2Îµ2+nÎµ)Î˜superscriptğœ2superscriptğœ€2ğ‘›ğœ€\Theta\big{(}\frac{\sigma^{2}}{\varepsilon^{2}}+\frac{n}{\varepsilon}\big{)} in terms of the gradients computed. Our convergence rate given in TheoremÂ 6 coincides with this lower bound as in this case concurrency Ï„C=nsubscriptğœğ¶ğ‘›\tau_{C}=n, Ï„aâ€‹vâ€‹g=Ï„Â¯C=n2subscriptğœğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘”subscriptÂ¯ğœğ¶ğ‘›2\tau_{avg}=\bar{\tau}_{C}=\frac{n}{2}.

5 Heterogeneous Distributed Setting

In this section we consider more general problems of the form (1) where the functions fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i} are different on different nodes. This setting is motivated for example by federated learning [33, 23], where every node (client) possesses its own private data, possibly coming from a different data distribution, and thus has its own different local loss function fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i}.

The setting here is therefore more general than the one considered in previous SectionÂ 4, and we will see that some of the results (with the constant stepsizes) in the homogeneous case follow as a special case of the more general results we present in this section.

5.1 Algorithm

We consider asynchronous SGD as given in AlgorithmÂ 2. Close variants of this algorithm were studied in several prior works [36, 46]. In order to simplify the presentation, we consider that concurrency is constant over time (and thus Ï„C=Ï„Â¯Csubscriptğœğ¶subscriptÂ¯ğœğ¶\tau_{C}=\bar{\tau}_{C} in DefinitionÂ 1). In order to allow for client subsampling often implemented in practical FL applications, we allow the concurrency Ï„Csubscriptğœğ¶\tau_{C} to be smaller than overall number of workers nğ‘›n. The same concurrency model was recently considered in the practical FedBuff algorithm [36].

The algorithm is very similar to the homogeneous AlgorithmÂ 1 with two key differences: at line 6, the server selects clients out of all clients, and does so uniformly at random, regardless of the current active worker set ğ’tsubscriptğ’ğ‘¡\mathcal{C}_{t}. This means that the same client can get sampled several times, even if it didnâ€™t finish its previous job(s) yet (thus ğ’tsubscriptğ’ğ‘¡\mathcal{C}_{t} is a multiset). In this case, the assigned jobs would just pile up on this client.

5.2 Theoretical analysis

We first note that our key observation on the delays (Remark 5) holds for AlgorithmÂ 2 as well. Moreover, as we have a constant concurrency Ï„Csubscriptğœğ¶\tau_{C} at every step, Ï„aâ€‹vâ€‹g=ğ’ªâ€‹(Ï„C)subscriptğœğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘”ğ’ªsubscriptğœğ¶\tau_{avg}=\mathcal{O}\!\left(\tau_{C}\right).

Definition 10.

Denote a (possibly empty) set {Ï„kCT,i}ksubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğœğ‘˜subscriptğ¶ğ‘‡ğ‘–ğ‘˜\{\tau_{k}^{C_{T},i}\}_{k} to be the set of delays from gradients of the client iğ‘–i that are left unapplied at the last iteration of the AlgorithmÂ 2.

We define the average delay of a client iğ‘–i as

Ï„aâ€‹vâ€‹gi=1Tiâ€‹(âˆ‘t:jt=iÏ„t+âˆ‘kÏ„kCT,i)superscriptsubscriptğœğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘”ğ‘–1subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘–subscript:ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘—ğ‘¡ğ‘–subscriptğœğ‘¡subscriptğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğœğ‘˜subscriptğ¶ğ‘‡ğ‘–\displaystyle\tau_{avg}^{i}=\frac{1}{T_{i}}\left(\sum_{t~{}:~{}j_{t}=i}\tau_{t}+\sum_{k}\tau_{k}^{C_{T},i}\right)

where Tisubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘–T_{i} is the number of times the client iğ‘–i got sampled during lines 1 and 6 of AlgorithmÂ 2.

Assumption 5.

The average delay Ï„aâ€‹vâ€‹gisuperscriptsubscriptğœğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘”ğ‘–\tau_{avg}^{i} is independent from the number of times Tisubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘–T_{i} the client iğ‘–i got sampled.

Theorem 11 (constant stepsizes).

Under Assumptions 1, 2, 3, 5 there is exist a constant stepsize Î·tâ‰¡Î·subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡ğœ‚\eta_{t}\equiv\eta such that for AlgorithmÂ 2 it holds that 1T+1â€‹âˆ‘t=0Tâˆ¥âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ±(t))âˆ¥22â‰¤Îµ1ğ‘‡1superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡0ğ‘‡superscriptsubscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥âˆ‡ğ‘“superscriptğ±ğ‘¡22ğœ€\frac{1}{T+1}\sum_{t=0}^{T}\left\lVert\nabla f(\mathbf{x}^{(t)})\right\rVert_{2}^{2}\leq\varepsilon after

ğ’ªâ€‹(Ïƒ2Îµ2+Î¶2Îµ2+Ï„aâ€‹vâ€‹gâ€‹1nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nÎ¶i2â€‹Ï„aâ€‹vâ€‹giÎµ32+Ï„aâ€‹vâ€‹gâ€‹Ï„maxÎµ)ğ’ªsuperscriptğœ2superscriptğœ€2superscriptğœ2superscriptğœ€2subscriptğœğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘”1ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğœğ‘–2subscriptsuperscriptğœğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘”superscriptğœ€32subscriptğœğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘”subscriptğœğœ€\displaystyle\mathcal{O}\!\left(\frac{\sigma^{2}}{\varepsilon^{2}}+\frac{\zeta^{2}}{\varepsilon^{2}}+\frac{\sqrt{\tau_{avg}\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\zeta_{i}^{2}\tau^{i}_{avg}}}{\varepsilon^{\frac{3}{2}}}+\frac{\sqrt{\tau_{avg}\tau_{\max}}}{\varepsilon}\right) iterations, (14)

Under AssumptionsÂ  1, 2, 3 and additional bounded gradient AssumptionÂ 4, it holds that 1T+1â€‹âˆ‘t=0Tâˆ¥âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ±(t))âˆ¥22â‰¤Îµ1ğ‘‡1superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡0ğ‘‡superscriptsubscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥âˆ‡ğ‘“superscriptğ±ğ‘¡22ğœ€\frac{1}{T+1}\sum_{t=0}^{T}\left\lVert\nabla f(\mathbf{x}^{(t)})\right\rVert_{2}^{2}\leq\varepsilon after

ğ’ªâ€‹(Ïƒ2Îµ2+Î¶2Îµ2+Ï„aâ€‹vâ€‹gâ€‹GÎµ32+Ï„aâ€‹vâ€‹gÎµ)ğ’ªsuperscriptğœ2superscriptğœ€2superscriptğœ2superscriptğœ€2subscriptğœğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘”ğºsuperscriptğœ€32subscriptğœğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘”ğœ€\displaystyle\mathcal{O}\!\left(\frac{\sigma^{2}}{\varepsilon^{2}}+\frac{\zeta^{2}}{\varepsilon^{2}}+\frac{\tau_{avg}G}{\varepsilon^{\frac{3}{2}}}+\frac{\tau_{avg}}{\varepsilon}\right) iterations. (15)

We note that the leading 1Îµ21superscriptğœ€2\frac{1}{\varepsilon^{2}} term is affected by heterogeneity Î¶2superscriptğœ2\zeta^{2} because at every step we apply gradient from only one client. This term is usually present in the federated learning algorithms with client subsampling see e.g. [24].

5.3 Discussion

Comparison to other works.

The recent FedBuff algorithm [36] is similar to our AlgorithmÂ 2. Their algorithm allows clients to perform several local steps and the server to wait for more than 1 client to finish compute (aka buffering), which we did not include for simplicity as these aspects are orthogonal to the effect of delays.

Disregarding these two orthogonal changes, the FedBuff algorithm is almost equivalent to our AlgorithmÂ 2 with a key difference: they assume that the client jtsubscriptğ‘—ğ‘¡j_{t} that finishes computation at every step comes from the uniform distribution over all the clients. This is unrealistic to assume in practice because the server cannot control which clients finish computations at every step. In AlgorithmÂ 2 we have the more realistic assumption only on the sampling process of the clients (on line 6) that can be controlled by the server. This reflects practical client sampling in federated learning.

The convergence rate of FedBuff [36] under the bounded gradient assumption is ğ’ªâ€‹(Ïƒ2Îµ2+Î¶2Îµ2+(Î¶2+1)â€‹Ï„maxâ€‹G2Îµ)ğ’ªsuperscriptğœ2superscriptğœ€2superscriptğœ2superscriptğœ€2superscriptğœ21subscriptğœsuperscriptğº2ğœ€\mathcal{O}\!\left(\frac{\sigma^{2}}{\varepsilon^{2}}+\frac{\zeta^{2}}{\varepsilon^{2}}+\frac{(\zeta^{2}+1)\tau_{\max}G^{2}}{\varepsilon}\right). In contrast, in TheoremÂ 11 we completely remove the dependence on the maximum delay Ï„maxsubscriptğœ\tau_{\max} under bounded gradients (as in Equation (15)).

Delays.

We note that for TheoremÂ 11 we did not impose any assumption on the delays. Thus, our result allows clients and the delays on these clients to be dependent, meaning that some of the clients could be systematically slower than others. Interestingly, the middle heterogeneity term (the term with Î¶isubscriptğœğ‘–\zeta_{i}) is not affected by the maximum delay at all, but is affected by the average delay within each individual client. If all the heterogeneity parameters are equal, i.e. Î¶i=Î¶j,âˆ€i,jsubscriptğœğ‘–subscriptğœğ‘—for-allğ‘–ğ‘—\zeta_{i}=\zeta_{j},\forall i,j, then the middle term will be affected only by the overall average delay Ï„aâ€‹vâ€‹gsubscriptğœğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘”\tau_{avg}.

Gradient clipping.

Practical implementations of FL algorithms usually apply clipping to the gradients in order to guarantee differential privacy [23]. This automatically bounds the norm of all applied gradients, making the the constant G2superscriptğº2G^{2} in AssumptionÂ 4 small. Although we do not provide formal convergence guarantees of asynchronous SGD with gradient clipping, we envision that its convergence rate would depend only on the average delay, similar to the bounded gradient case (9), thus making the algorithm robust to stragglers.

Delay-adaptive stepsizes.

For homogeneous functions we have shown that delay-adaptive stepsizes result in a convergence rate dependent only on the average delay Ï„aâ€‹vâ€‹gsubscriptğœğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘”\tau_{avg} without assuming bounded gradients (as in Equation (11)). However in the heterogeneous case this is not so straightforward. Delay-adaptive learning rate schemes will introduce a bias towards the clients that compute quickly, and AlgorithmÂ 2 would converge to the wrong objective.

It is interesting to note that current popular schemes implemented in practice for FL over-selects the clients at every iteration [11]. The server waits only for some percentage (e.g. 80%) of sampled clients and discards the rest. Such a scheme also introduces a bias towards fast workers. A delay-adaptive learning rate scheme is expected to introduce less bias as the gradients are still applied but with the smaller weight. We leave this question for future practical investigations, as it is not the focus of our current work.

Independent delays.

If the delays and the clients are independent (e.g. coming from the same distribution for all of the clients), then the convergence rate of AlgorithmÂ 2 will simplify to ğ’ªâ€‹(Ïƒ2Îµ2+Î¶â€‹Ï„aâ€‹vâ€‹gÎµ32+Ï„aâ€‹vâ€‹gâ€‹Ï„maxÎµ)ğ’ªsuperscriptğœ2superscriptğœ€2ğœsubscriptğœğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘”superscriptğœ€32subscriptğœğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘”subscriptğœğœ€\mathcal{O}\!\left(\frac{\sigma^{2}}{\varepsilon^{2}}+\frac{\zeta\tau_{avg}}{\varepsilon^{\frac{3}{2}}}+\frac{\sqrt{\tau_{avg}\tau_{\max}}}{\varepsilon}\right) (without needing bounded gradient assumption). In this case it is also possible to use delay-adaptive stepsizes (similar to TheoremÂ 8) to completely remove the dependence on the maximum delays Ï„maxsubscriptğœ\tau_{\max} without assuming bounded gradients.

Extensions.

We can extend the AlgorithmÂ 2 and our theoretical analysis to allow clients to perform several local steps, before sending back the change in ğ±ğ±\mathbf{x}. We can also extend AlgorithmÂ 2 to allow the server to wait for the first Kğ¾K clients to finish computations rather than just one, similar to [36]. These extensions are straightforward and we excluded them here for simplicity of presentation.

Finally, we can also extend AlgorithmÂ 2 to sample new clients as soon as some previous client finished compute, without waiting for the server update on the line 5.

5.4 Estimating Speedup over Synchronous SGD

Assume we have nğ‘›n clients, each of which having a different but constant time to compute a gradient {Î”i}i=1nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptÎ”ğ‘–ğ‘–1ğ‘›\{\Delta_{i}\}_{i=1}^{n}. W.l.o.g. we assume that Î”isubscriptÎ”ğ‘–\Delta_{i} are ordered as Î”1â‰¤Î”2â‰¤â‹¯â‰¤Î”nsubscriptÎ”1subscriptÎ”2â‹¯subscriptÎ”ğ‘›\Delta_{1}\leq\Delta_{2}\leq\dots\leq\Delta_{n}.

Lemma 12.

In expectation, the asynchronous AlgorithmÂ 2 needs

Î”Â¯=1nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nÎ”iÂ¯Î”1ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›subscriptÎ”ğ‘–\displaystyle\bar{\Delta}=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\Delta_{i}

time to compute Ï„Csubscriptğœğ¶\tau_{C} gradients, while mini-batch SGD with batch size Ï„Csubscriptğœğ¶\tau_{C} needs

Î”~=âˆ‘i=1nÎ±iâ€‹Î”i~Î”superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›subscriptğ›¼ğ‘–subscriptÎ”ğ‘–\displaystyle\tilde{\Delta}=\sum_{i=1}^{n}\alpha_{i}\Delta_{i}

time to compute a batch of Ï„Csubscriptğœğ¶\tau_{C} gradients, where Î±i=iÏ„Câˆ’(iâˆ’1)Ï„CnÏ„Csubscriptğ›¼ğ‘–superscriptğ‘–subscriptğœğ¶superscriptğ‘–1subscriptğœğ¶superscriptğ‘›subscriptğœğ¶\alpha_{i}=\frac{i^{\tau_{C}}-(i-1)^{\tau_{C}}}{n^{\tau_{C}}}. It is also always holds that Î”Â¯â‰¤Î”~Â¯Î”~Î”\bar{\Delta}\leq\tilde{\Delta}.

With this lemma we can precisely estimate how much faster the asynchronous algorithm is compared to the classic synchronous mini-batch one. Note that Î±isubscriptğ›¼ğ‘–\alpha_{i} are increasing with iğ‘–i with a rate of ğ’ªâ€‹(iÏ„C)ğ’ªsuperscriptğ‘–subscriptğœğ¶\mathcal{O}(i^{\tau_{C}}), thus in mini-batch SGD, the large delays get a much higher weight than the small delays, especially when the batch size Ï„Csubscriptğœğ¶\tau_{C} is large.

For example, consider 100010001000 clients, 900900900 of which compute their update every 101010s, while 100100100 of them computes their update every 60â€‹s60ğ‘ 60s. Then the expected time for Ï„Csubscriptğœğ¶\tau_{C} gradients of the asynchronous algorithm will be 151515s, while synchronous mini-batch SGD (with Ï„C=10subscriptğœğ¶10\tau_{C}=10) will take a significantly longer time of 42.542.542.5s for the same number of gradients.

6 Conclusion

In this paper we study the asynchronous SGD algorithm both in homogeneous and heterogeneous settings. By leveraging the notion of concurrencyâ€”the number of workers that compute gradients in parallelâ€”we show a much faster convergence rate for asynchronous SGD, improving the dependence on the maximum delay Ï„maxsubscriptğœ\tau_{\max} over prior works, for both homogeneous and heterogeneous objectives. Our proof technique also allows to design a simple delay-adaptive stepsize ruleÂ (11) that attains a convergence rate depending only on the average delay Ï„aâ€‹vâ€‹gsubscriptğœğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘”\tau_{avg} that neither requires any additional tuning, nor additional communication. Our techniques allows us to demonstrate that asynchronous SGD is faster than mini-batch SGD for any delay pattern.

A.6 Proof of LemmaÂ 12

In this section we prove LemmaÂ 12 that estimates expected execution time of AlgorithmÂ 2 with concurrency Ï„C=Csubscriptğœğ¶ğ¶\tau_{C}=C, and the expected time of mini-batch SGD with the same concurrency i.e.Â batch size equal to Ï„C=Csubscriptğœğ¶ğ¶\tau_{C}=C.

Proof.

We start by proving the first claim.

Time of Asynchronous AlgorithmÂ 2.

Assume the concurrency is C=1ğ¶1C=1. Then, AlgorithmÂ 2 is synchronous, and as we sample every client with equal probability (line 6 of AlgorithmÂ 2), the expected time to compute one gradient is equal to 1nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nÎ”i1ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›subscriptÎ”ğ‘–\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\Delta_{i}.

To calculate the estimated time with concurrency C>1ğ¶1C>1 we can view the AlgorithmÂ 2 as having Cğ¶C independent copies of the previous process run in parallel. Thus, in the same time 1nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nÎ”i1ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›subscriptÎ”ğ‘–\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\Delta_{i} in expectation AlgorithmÂ 2 will compute Cğ¶C gradients.

Time of Mini-batch SGD.

Appendix B Experiments

In this set of experiments we aim to illustrate the dependence on the maximum delay Ï„maxsubscriptğœ\tau_{\max} in TheoremÂ 6, as depicted in Equation (8). For this, we set the stochastic noise Ïƒğœ\sigma to zero. In this case TheoremÂ 6, Equation (8) predicts that to reach an Îµğœ€\varepsilon accuracy, AlgorithmÂ 1 needs T=ğ’ªâ€‹(Ï„maxâ€‹Ï„CÎµ)ğ‘‡ğ’ªsubscriptğœsubscriptğœğ¶ğœ€T=\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{\sqrt{\tau_{\max}\tau_{C}}}{\varepsilon}\right) iterations.
